instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

threads.title: A1286 820-2850 2010 MACBOOK PRO A1286 can't log in OS, shut down, CPU panics
threads.message:
Im having a 820-2850 board, thought it was common issue with the c9560. replaced with 330 capacitor and it's still doing the same thing.
having shut down usually once log into OS or have all the error codes during boot up. please see attached image.
any suggestions will be apprecaited

threads.title: A1286 820-2850 2010 MACBOOK PRO A1286 can't log in OS, shut down, CPU panics
threads.message: I would first suspect bad RAM or a bad RAM slot.

threads.title: A1286 820-2850 2010 MACBOOK PRO A1286 can't log in OS, shut down, CPU panics
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 7398"]I would first suspect bad RAM or a bad RAM slot.[/QUOTE]

but didn't it say something fault CPU? it's not the RAMS i tried couple already and check the slot with microscope ,they all look tight and fine

threads.title: A1286 820-2850 2010 MACBOOK PRO A1286 can't log in OS, shut down, CPU panics
threads.message: Did you try 1 slot at a time?

threads.title: A1286 820-2850 2010 MACBOOK PRO A1286 can't log in OS, shut down, CPU panics
threads.message: figured out, it is the ram slot! but how to fix it, it's the slot on the back side(the side with the video memory) ,can only drag solder the pins I can reach, but seems like there are still pins inside using BGA attached to the board?

threads.title: A1286 820-2850 2010 MACBOOK PRO A1286 can't log in OS, shut down, CPU panics
threads.message: You don't! Just max out the working slot with 8GB.

threads.title: A1286 820-2850 2010 MACBOOK PRO A1286 can't log in OS, shut down, CPU panics
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 7475"]You don't! Just max out the working slot with 8GB.[/QUOTE]

got it. yea I guess that's the only way to go, the guy is a picky guy and hope i can get it through by talking.
thank you man
